Author: anrecovery
Text: dude this narrative sounds EXACTLY like my situation   taught my dad to use MFP, because that’s how i became obsessed w weight loss, and now he’s addicted. sucks over christmas having him immediately go for a walk after eating to “burn some extra calories”.  all he talks about now is finding new low cal foods, fitting into new clothes, and i have to sit and watch him after every meal enter every thing he’s ate into MFP.  it’s super triggering for me as well. my dad has told me too that if he goes over his calorie limit for the day, he’ll eat less the next day.... to me that sounds like the beginning steps of an ED lmao but he doesn’t think anything’s wrong with it and plans to use MFP the rest of his life  ugh. what have we done lol

Author: grossenten98
Text: Dang, that’s got to be a ton to take in. I’d find it pretty triggering also.  My family is doing quite the opposite, I’m exhausted by seeing my family members with diabetes and heart disease k!ll themselves with unhealthy eating, they don’t even understand calories/macros, they drink sodas right and left. It’s wild I would help the but it’s not worth the risk on my part, they’d be like’what are you starving yourself?!’   One thing that I two myself and my friends with EDs, is to “get better” for you and just yourself, don’t recover or get healthier to please. Do it for your own performance. That mindset of putting myself first helped me so much. Oh, and don’t get me started on my grandparents trying to lose weight, they fat shamed themselves, it was torture XD
